{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2990938,"name":"Nicholas Carpenedo","username":"Indigo2003","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-13T19:21:47.550Z","cooked":"

Trying to do some theoretical calculations about robot acceleration out of curiosity. I have one simple question about the nature of DC motors though. Does the drivetrain draw stall current at the moment the robot starts accelerating from rest (assuming adequate traction)?

With my (limited) understanding of DC motors, I would expect that the torque of the drivetrain would be stall torque at rest, and the current draw and torque would decrease as velocity increases. Is this accurate?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-13T19:21:47.550Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":79,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":424.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Nicholas Carpenedo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37932,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/1","custom_user_title":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":2990972,"name":"Eric Tate","username":"MrT8","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrt8/{size}/9889_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-13T19:43:46.324Z","cooked":"

You would only develop stall torque at rest if you have the full 12Vdc applied to the motor. The FRC speed controllers alter the effective voltage applied at the motor terminals though what is known as Pulse Width Modulation (PWM). The Free Speed (unloaded shaft speed) and Stall Torque (torque at zero shaft speed) are roughly linear in proportion to the effective voltage applied to the motor terminals.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-13T23:40:03.415Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":131,"readers_count":130,"score":31.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Eric Tate","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31332,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2990982,"name":"Nicholas Carpenedo","username":"Indigo2003","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-13T19:51:31.568Z","cooked":"

So if the motor controller delivers full voltage, then stall torque is achieved for a moment? Also, how does this not trip the 40A breaker considering that stall current (for a CIM) is upwards of 130A?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-13T19:51:31.568Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":112,"readers_count":111,"score":27.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Nicholas Carpenedo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":31332,"username":"MrT8","name":"Eric Tate","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrt8/{size}/9889_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37932,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/3","custom_user_title":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2990983,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-13T19:52:09.005Z","cooked":"

The breakers are capable of handling higher than the rated current for short periods of time.

Oh ok, the math works out then. Thanks!

Totally off-topic, but do you know how to calculate the inertial moment of a belt and pulley? I know I=kmr^2 for a single wheel, but what about for a typical belt and pulley mechanism with a belt rotating around a set of pulleys?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-13T23:39:31.000Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":76,"readers_count":75,"score":25.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Nicholas Carpenedo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":22335,"username":"GeeTwo","name":"Gus Michel II","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37932,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/5","custom_user_title":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2991166,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-13T23:55:42.095Z","cooked":"

Depends crucially on what‚Äôs attached to those pulleys. The angular momentum of each axle adds.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-13T23:55:42.095Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":73,"readers_count":72,"score":24.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":37932,"username":"Indigo2003","name":"Nicholas Carpenedo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/57b2e6/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/6","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2991175,"name":"Nicholas Carpenedo","username":"Indigo2003","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-14T00:25:24.343Z","cooked":"

Ok, let‚Äôs say for the sake of easy numbers:
2 axles with one 5cm diameter pulley on each axle. Total mass of a single axle is 0.1kg. A belt weighing 0.05kg. Nothing is attached to the pulley except for a motor, so the entire mechanism would be 2 axles, 1 belt, 1 motor.

Is the moment of inertia just the sum of the moment of inertia for each axle? Is the moment of inertia of the belt factored in?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-14T00:25:24.343Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":66,"readers_count":65,"score":13.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Nicholas Carpenedo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37932,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/7","custom_user_title":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer","reactions":[{"id":"hugs","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2991197,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-14T01:09:47.291Z","cooked":"

The belt will definitely be factored in. If you‚Äôre doing a pure MoI, the distance between the pulleys becomes a factor, as does the axis you‚Äôre interested in. If you‚Äôre worried about this for purposes of applying the torque to the system with the axles themselves being stationary, letting the masses be represented by the first consonant of each item, r be the radius of the axles, and R be the pitch radius of the pulleys: each axle is xr¬≤/2, each pulley (assuming solid) is about pR¬≤/2*, and the belt is bR¬≤, for a grand total of xr¬≤ + (p+b)R¬≤ plus the motors armature.
Assuming the motor drives the axle directly (no reduction), and that the armature is 1/3 of the mass of the motor (m) and its mean square radiusis 2/3 the radius of the motor, œÅ (SWAGs), that would be 4mœÅ¬≤/27.

* The actual outside radius of the pulley is a bit smaller than R, but there‚Äôs a hole in the middle. The two effects offset, so let‚Äôs just let them cancel for jazz. Letting the mean ‚Äúradius‚Äù of the belt be the pitch radius is actually a pretty good approximation.

SWAG

Scientific Wild Guess

Behind the Scenes, to answer the more general question

The thing I‚Äôm really calculating here is the ratio of the kinetic energy of the system to the squared angular speed of the motor. For a simple rotating system, this is the moment of inertia.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-14T01:19:11.406Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":31.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/8","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2991199,"name":"Nicholas Carpenedo","username":"Indigo2003","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-14T01:19:13.647Z","cooked":"

Wow perfect! Thanks so much. And ‚Äúradius of the axles‚Äù means the distance between the axles * 0.5 right? Also I love the swag

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-14T01:19:56.287Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":51,"readers_count":50,"score":30.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Nicholas Carpenedo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":22335,"username":"GeeTwo","name":"Gus Michel II","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37932,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/9","custom_user_title":"6884 Co-Captain & Lead Programmer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2991201,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-14T01:20:04.639Z","cooked":"

No, the radius of the axles themselves. I‚Äôm guessing about half or 3/8 of in inch diameter, most likely, so 1/4" or 3/16".

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2022-01-14T01:20:45.628Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":14.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":400092,"topic_slug":"dc-motor-torque","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":37932,"username":"Indigo2003","name":"Nicholas Carpenedo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/57b2e6/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/dc-motor-torque/400092/10","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2991202,"name":"Nicholas Carpenedo","username":"Indigo2003","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/57b2e6/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-14T01:21:20.774Z","cooked":"

Oh ok. You said at the beginning of your answer that the distance between the pulleys becomes a factor but I don‚Äôt see that reflected in the math. Am I missing something?

If you want true MOI, yes it will matter - but then you‚Äôre calculating the inertia for rotating the whole assembly around one axis, likely the motor‚Äôs axis. I‚Äôm assuming that both axles will spin on essentially stationary axes in post 8.
